708212f-a.text:
Fourth Avenue, north from East 21st Street, showing prominently the west side of this thoroughfare.  The important structures appearing are, the Bank for Savings (site under preparation in 1892); the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church; the Y. M. C. A.; the Academy of Design; Madison Square Garden and the Hotel Park Avenue.  Across the top appears the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. building (part under construction); the spire atop the old Madison Presbyterian Church, and the tower of the huge Madison Square Garden.  On the right are architectural details of Calvary Church and its adjoining Church Mission House P. E. (site cleared in 1892)

About 1895

Gift of Urbroock Collection

708218f-a.text:
Fourth Avenue, north from a point between E. 21st and 22nd Streets, photographed to show constructional details of the Lexington Avenue Subway.  E. 22nd Street is in the foreground, occupying respectively the S.E., N.E., and N.W. corners of ? are the Board of Foreign Missions Building, the United Charities Building and the 4th Avenue Presbyterian Church.

November 5, 1900

708211f-a.text:
Fourth Avenue, east side, north from 21st Street. On the N.W. corner of 21st Street stands Calvary (Protestant Episcopal) Church, build in 1847.  The Church Mission House occupies the rest of the block above the church.  The other buildings will all be torn down and replaced by office buildings.
1906
Brown Brothers, Photographers

708213f-a.text:
West side of Fourth Avenue north from, 21st Street.  White building in right center opened and occupied by Provident Loan(?) Society.  The next building north is the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church, now demolished.
1906
Brown Brothers, Photographers

708216f.text:
North on Fourth Avenue from 21st Street.
Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. tower is seen at right foreground

About 1910.

733343f-a.title: Strikes and demonstrations.
733343f-a.text:
Striking Cloak and Suit Makers lined up before office of Joint Board, Cloak & Suit Makers' Union 34 E. 21st Street to draw their allowances of $2.00 each.  The line, four deep, reached down to 4th Ave., and around the corner to 20th St.  About $80,000 is paid (to) strikers each week by the Board
1916
733343f-a.folder: 21st Street and 4th Avenue ; 34 East 21st Street  , Manhattan, N.Y.

711577f-a.text:
36-34-32 East 21st Street, south side, between Fourth Avenue and Broadway.  No. 32, at the right, is the Fischer Building.
June, 1925
